body:
FYI: @kotarella1110 i think there r some issue with useFieldArray, i am busy working over all the issues. next release should make it more solid, that's also the reason i haven't response most of the issues today.

also you want to help to send a PR on those issue you reported on one of the PR. üëç

> It works correctly if you remove uncomment the line.

Confirmed this works in my local code.  I'm almost certain I had `defaultValue`  set before and the bug was still present, but I've been hacking away on my code in different areas, so it's likely I missed when the break occurred.   I upgraded from 4.5.6 to 4.6.2 in the process of making these changes.  It's possible setting `defaultValue` didn't work as expected in the earlier version. 

Not completely sure why `defaultValue` was commented out.  The codesandbox is one linked from the official docs [here](https://react-hook-form.com/api#useFieldArray) (the codesandbox link in the second code block under `useFieldArray`). 

Thanks for looking into this ‚≠êÔ∏è
There is a beta version, feel free to help on testing.
FYI: also it's safer to inject `defaultValues` than `defaultValue`, because defaultValue will overwrite value after each re-render.

Looks like this might still be broken.  Here's the sandbox from earlier, updated to 4.7.0-beta.1 and simplified to include only the basics https://codesandbox.io/s/react-hook-form-usefieldarray-23851.  If you follow the same steps to reproduce the original report, you should see it empties all values now.   Setting `defaultValue` "fixes" the issue, but it seems like we should avoid this based on your suggestion.

hey @caged it's not really broken. I guess it's a trade-off of being uncontrolled. 

with Controlled state represent the shape of the input, however it does require everything to be in sync, which why each input required a re-render and map every keystroke.

with Uncontrolled, if set default value for individual input, it will get injected each re-render caused by action eg: pre-pend, swap, move and etc. I will update the documentation to reflect that and hence it's better to set up your defaultValues at the `form` level. hope these make sense and feel free to follow up with more questions.
want to try out this beta: `4.7.0-beta.2`?
hey @caged I have released the latest minor update with useFieldArray. let me know if this improve things.

4.7.0 appears to behave the same way üò¢.  I feel like I'm taking up too much of your time with this, since I have a workaround.  I also have a sneaking suspicion, we might have our wires crossed and the workaround isn't a workaround at all, but the correct way to use the field array hook.  

To sum it up:
* [This codesandbox](https://codesandbox.io/s/react-hook-form-usefieldarray-23851) perfectly demonstrates the default behavior with the suggested use, and the behavior when you uncomment `defaultValue` on the input.  Without `defaultValue` set on the input, `append` doesn't actually set the input value and removing an item clears the form.
* You need to set `defaultValues` (plural) at the form level (`useForm`) _and_ `defaultValue`  the input level (`<input defaultValue={field.value} />`) for `useFieldArray` to work reasonably well (e.g. not delete a users previously entered content).  
* This doesn't appear to have any negative drawbacks, and it's almost as if it's the intended use.  If this is the case, nothing is broken and all is right.  
* My confusion stems from your comment discouraging adding `defaultValue` at the input level.  Even if it's set to the values passed in with `fields`.  Without doing this, the behavior appears to be broken.

Thanks again for your time and have a great weekend! üçª
